Award.AwardTitle: Nebraska Conference for Undergraduate Women in Mathematics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the Nebraska Conference for Undergraduate Women in Mathematics (NCUWM) to be held annually for three years beginning in the winter of 2016 at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. The conference brings together women undergraduate math majors from all over the United States for the purposes of encouraging them to go to graduate school in mathematics or a related field and increasing the success of those who do. NCUWM pursues these goals through a variety of activities. Two plenary talks by prominent female mathematicians show that women have made, and are continuing to make, exceptional research contributions. Also featured are 48 talks and a larger number of posters by undergraduate women about their own research; these presentations provide valuable experience for the women who give them and serve to motivate the less experienced women to find opportunities to do research projects. Panel discussions demonstrate how mathematics offers natural and rewarding career choices for women and provide the undergraduate participants with insider knowledge and personal experiences that help them choose a graduate school and be successful. There are also a variety of networking activities that help participants connect with peers and mentors.

NCUWM plays an important role in inspiring young women to pursue mathematics. In addition to anecdotal evidence from former NCUWM attendees who earned PhDs in mathematics, an assessment report prepared after the 2015 conference concluded that NCUWM strongly influences the attitudes and beliefs of the undergraduate participants about pursuing graduate-level mathematics and mathematics related careers and that the conference significantly contributes to the professional growth of participants at all career levels. Plenary and invited speakers at the 2016 conference include mathematicians Emina Soljanin, Bell Laboratories; Abigail Thompson, University of California Davis; Alejandra Alvarado, Eastern Illinois University; Lorena Bociu, North Carolina State University; Johanna Franklin, Hofstra University; Emilie Hogan, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory; and Cristina Polizu, Standard and Poors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For 21 years, the Nebraska Conference for Undergraduate Women in Mathematics (NCUWM) has been inspiring students to pursue graduate school and careers in mathematics. This annual conference for outstanding undergraduate mathematicians was celebrated from 2016 to 2019 as part of National Science Foundation award DUE-1551087 and held in Lincoln, Nebraska. Undergraduates had the opportunity to meet others who shared their interest in the mathematical sciences, and students who already had done research were given an opportunity to present their results.

NCUWM's overall goal is to arm participants with knowledge, self-confidence, and a network of peers to help them become successful mathematicians. Conference participants also have a chance to learn about life in graduate school from the perspective of current women graduate students representing math departments from across the country.

Over this grant, 957 undergraduates attended. The 2019 conference saw 242 undergraduate participants from 119 institutions and featured three plenary speakers: Christine Darden (NASA Executive Service, retired, and featured in the book "Hidden Figures"), Zhilan Feng (Purdue University), and Margaret Holen (Princeton University; Goldman Sachs, retired). Other plenary speakers were Jill Pipher (Brown University) and Irena Swanson (Reed College) in 2018; Ami Radunskaya (Pomona College, California) and Brooke Shipley (University of Illinois at Chicago) in 2017; Emina Soljanin (Rutgers University) and Abigail Thompson (University of California, Davis) in 2016.

The principal components of the program were the plenary talks and the talks and posters by undergraduate students, but the NCUWM experience included a number of events whose purpose was to share information and make personal connections. There were three panel discussions, including one on Choosing a Graduate School and another on Careers in Mathematics, as well as 20 different topics for small-group breakout sessions, including Getting Ready for Graduate School, Juggling Graduate School and Your Social Life, and Summer Opportunities for Undergraduates. The conferences also featured a networking dinner in which students joined a table with a professional mathematician for an informal small-group conversation.

Plenary speaker videos can be viewed online at https://go.unl.edu/ncuwm or on the Nebraska Mathematics YouTube channel.

This conference continues to be held annually by the University of Nebraska-Lincoln Department of Mathematics, with support from the National Science Foundation and the National Security Agency. The conference was held in-person in 2020 and online in 2021.
